sentences.text: hey, Eliza.
Hey, can you hear me?
Hello?
Yes.
Oh, perfect.
And is it Liza or Liza?
It's Liza?
Liza.
Nice to meet you, Liza.
Nice to meet you.
Where are you calling out of today?
From London UK.
Oh, very cool.
I'm based out of Brooklyn New York.
Oh, nice.
But I appreciate you hopping on the call here today.
So just to set a quick agenda here, we'd love to do a round of introductions, understand your role, what got you interested in hiver?
Then we can jump into a product demonstration, and then we'll just save some time at the end for any questions and next steps.
Yeah, sure.
Perfect.
So I can introduce myself first.
My name is Cole miller.
I'm a senior account executive here at hiver.
I've been in the email management, customer experience space for a little over six years now, and yeah, just looking forward to seeing how we can help you all today.
Nice.
So, yeah, my name is Liza.
I work with reddot for about… a year, but I worked with these people before in the… past.
So, yeah, because the founder Kelly, he founded kind of the previous company where I was, so, yeah, kind of followed them and I'm currently actually looking after product.
I'm more of like a product manager.
However, our team is not big and we sort of came to this point when we need like a support desk like a service desk.
And because in the past, I was actually leading the support teams like the client operations.
So this is why I'm helping out with setting up this kind of, you know, the software with them.
Okay.
So, and I noticed the team was on the trial, how's everything been so far since you've been using it?
I saw you set up a shared mailbox.
Is it primarily email the channel that you're managing?
Yeah.
Yes.
So, I think it's going well.
I've got, we've got kind of like on a meeting all together and shared feedback.
So I kind of compiled a list of questions.
So I will ask you about like just a few things just kind of double check even nothing too scary.
Let's say.
Gotcha.
So it seems like the team does want to move forward with hiver based on how it's been so far.
Okay.
Yeah, yeah, I think so.

So we tried atlassian service desk, but there were a few kind of things the team didn't like and I think it's just how it is.
I'm not, you can't really fix it.
So this is why we decided to try this.
And I think, yeah, the team like hiver a little bit more than, you know, atlassian product.
Right.
And we do have an integration with Jira.
So if you want to create tickets out into Jira, that is a possibility from hiver as well.
Yeah.
I mean, to be honest, we're probably not going to do that.

Right, right.
So this is just more for external support questions coming in managing.
Yeah, yeah, exactly.
Okay.
Exactly.
So I can run through a demonstration here real quick.
Just give you a rundown of hiver, you know, how we're helping similar teams and then, you know, feel free to stop and ask any questions as we're going through it.
But taking a look at my screen here, right?
And what's nice about hiver?
You know, we are a certified Google partner.
We live within that workspace.
And on the left hand side is where you're managing those shared inboxes or support emails as an organization.

So clicking on the support share mailbox, you know, as you click into it, you have the couple sub views beneath it, the unassigned view, you know, new emails that need to be delegated, the mine, everything that's been assigned to me.
And then the team view, you know, understanding in real time, what is everyone on the team working on?
What's outstanding and what needs to be completed and you can do things like bulk actions here.
So let's say, you know, I'm going out of office, I can select all my conversations and just reroute them in bulk to another team member to work.
Okay, nice.
Yeah.
And then you have, you can do bulk tags, you know, bulk change, status, things of that nature.
But going into the unassigned section, right?
The goal of hiver is to have unassigned zero.
We want no support tickets living in there.
We want everyone working on these conversations.
So I'll click into, you know, this email right here.
And when I do, we can do a couple of different things on the right hand side in this hiver tab.
The first is assign it to, you know, whoever you want to work it.
In this case, I'll assign it to myself.
The next way we can assign work is through a round Robin automation that will equally distribute the tickets or emails as they come into that support mailbox.
And then the last way Alisa is the skill based routing.
So identifying like keywords in the subject line, identifying keywords or phrases in the body of text and then routing to that specific person.
All right.
I'm going to pause there.
Any questions so far?
No, no, sounds good.
I'm not sure we're going to use the round Robin or the skill based assignment of tickets because like I said, the team is really small at this point, right?
Right.
Yeah, they probably don't really need it just yet.
Right.
No, that makes total sense.
Just kind of like first come first serve, just pick up conversations as they come in and assign them to yourself.
Right?
Yeah.
Then you have the status tracking.

So understanding where the conversation is and ensuring that nothing slips between the cracks, those tags for organizational purposes are really helpful for creating queues or folders based on these tags, you can also report on these tags on the back end to understand why people are reaching out?
What are the top questions or queries that we're getting across the mailbox?
Okay.
And then custom fields, oh, go ahead.

I'm just saying it makes sense.

Okay.

And then the last way is like skill based routing.

that's internal, that's the like internal notes here.
